Understate: The claim may understate the significance of the winning margin in Michigan by only mentioning the average of two votes per precinct. This could downplay the narrow margin and the potential impact it had on determining the outcome of the 2016 presidential race.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide additional evidence or data to support the assertion that the winning margin averaged out to just two votes per precinct. It relies solely on the statement made by Michelle Obama during her speech.
Exist alternative explanation: While the claim attributes the narrow winning margin to Michigan being one of the states that determined the outcome of the 2016 presidential race, it does not consider other factors or alternative explanations that may have contributed to the outcome.
Contradict fact: The claim does not contradict any known facts or information.
Exaggerate: The claim does not appear to exaggerate any information or make overstated claims.
Falters at times: The claim does not falter at times or display inconsistencies.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the narrow winning margin in Michigan was a significant factor in determining the outcome of the 2016 presidential race without providing further analysis or evidence to support this assumption.
